across.text: Composer in European city missing northern Australia
across.explanation: HectorBERLIOZ(i.e. “composer”). Solution is BERLIN (i.e. “European city”) with the N removed (indicated by “missing northern” – N being a recognised abbreviation of “northern”) and the remainder followed by OZ (i.e. slang for “Australia”), like so: BERLI-OZ. Ethan Coen’sHector Berlioz: Private Investigatoris a highlight of his short story collection,Garden of Eden. There a number of funny scenes where people keep mangling Berlioz’s surname. Worth a read if you can find a copy.

across.text: Coach gutted to stop swimming lesson in lake
across.explanation: LOCH NESS(i.e. “lake”). Solution is CH (i.e. “coach gutted”, i.e. the word “coach” with all its middle letters removed) placed in or “stopping” an anagram (indicated by “swimming”) of LESSON, like so: LO(CH)NESS.

across.text: Old singles also lacking energy
across.explanation: B-SIDES(i.e. “old singles” – ask your grandparents, kids). Solution is BESIDES (i.e. “also”) with the first E removed (indicated by “lacking energy” – E being a recognised abbreviation of “energy”).

across.text: Leader converting criminal to show great affection
across.explanation: TENDER LOVING CARE(i.e. “great affection”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “criminal”) of LEADER CONVERTING.

across.text: Sodium to handle a sickness
across.explanation: NAUSEA(i.e. “sickness”). Solution is NA (chemical symbol of “sodium”) followed by USE (i.e. “handle”) and A.

across.text: Say Arab has a personality disorder
across.explanation: EGOMANIA(i.e. “personality disorder”). Solution is EG (i.e. “say”, i.e. for example, after the Latinexempli gratia) followed by OMANI (i.e. an “Arab”) and A.

across.text: Spies with initially obtuse greeting
across.explanation: CIAO(i.e. “greeting” used on meeting or parting). Solution is CIA (i.e. “spies”, specifically the Central Intelligence Agency) followed by O (i.e. “initially obtuse”, i.e. the first letter of “obtuse”). Nicely worked.

across.text: Note above plate – fish caught by eccentric character
across.explanation: PLACE CARD(i.e. “note above plate” on a dinner table). Solution is a homophone (indicated by “caught”) of PLAICE (i.e. “fish”) followed by CARD (i.e. “eccentric character”).

across.text: Toothless Prime Minister introducing art gallery
across.explanation: EDENTATE(i.e. “toothless”). Solution is Anthony EDEN (i.e. 1950s “Prime Minister”) followed by TATE (i.e. an “art gallery”).

across.text: Campus race I organised – it’s a famous competition
across.explanation: AMERICA’S CUP(i.e. “a famous competition” in sailing). “Organised” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of CAMPUS RACE I.

across.text: Road feature’s traffic jam initially something very smooth
across.explanation: T-JUNCTION(i.e. “road feature”). Solution is T and J (i.e. “traffic jam initially”, i.e. the first and last letters of “traffic” and “jam”) followed by UNCTION (i.e. ointment or “something very smooth”).

across.text: Limit on filling beer for tax evader once
across.explanation: AL CAPONE(i.e. “tax evader once”). Solution is CAP (i.e. “limit”) and ON placed in or “filling” ALE (i.e. “beer”), like so: AL(CAP-ON)E.

across.text: Uninteresting place to live
across.explanation: FLAT. Solution satisfies “uninteresting” and “place to live”.

across.text: Where to store documents from a long investigation involving Tibet’s banks
across.explanation: ATTACHÉ CASE(i.e. “where to store documents”). Solution is A, ACHE (i.e. to “long” for someone) and CASE (i.e. an “investigation”) all wrapped around or “involving” TT (i.e. “Tibet’s banks”, i.e. the first and last letters of “Tibet”), like so: A-(TT)-ACHE-CASE.

across.text: State of solider – hand injured
across.explanation: RHODE ISLAND(i.e. US “state”). “Injured” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of SOLDIER HAND.

across.text: One on leave breaks extremely useful item in the tropics
across.explanation: MOSQUITO NET(i.e. “useful item in the tropics”). Solution is ONE placed “on” or after QUIT (i.e. to “leave”) and both then placed in or “breaking” MOST (i.e. “extremely”), like so: MOS(QUIT-ONE)T.

across.text: Perfect hosts make liquor
across.explanation: PEACH BRANDY(i.e. “liquor”). Solution is PEACHY (i.e. “perfect”) wrapped around or “hosting” BRAND (i.e. “make”), like so: PEACH(BRAND)Y. Very neat.

across.text: Invader loses article – that’s standard
across.explanation: NORM(i.e. “standard”). Solution is NORMAN (i.e. “invader” of the 10-11th century) with the AN removed (indicated by “loses article”, an article being a word like a, an or the).

across.text: Plot with cold fish goes bad in retrospect
across.explanation: STORY ARC(i.e. “plot”). Solution is C (a recognised abbreviation of “cold” used on taps), RAY (i.e. “fish”) and ROTS (i.e. “goes bad”) all reversed (indicated by “in retrospect”), like so: STOR-YAR-C.

across.text: Do signals, somehow producing a series of notes, played rapidly
across.explanation: GLISSANDO(i.e. “a series of notes, played rapidly” across a keyboard or stringed instrument). “Somehow” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of DO SIGNALS.

across.text: Jailbird struggles to accept time limits
across.explanation: CONSTRAINTS(i.e. “limits”). Solution is CON (i.e. “jailbird”, both slang words for prisoners) followed by STRAINS (i.e. “struggles”) once wrapped around or “accepting” T (a recognised abbreviation of “time”), like so: CON-STRAIN(T)S.

across.text: Regret backing competition that includes a German, say
across.explanation: EUROPEAN(i.e. “a German, say” – other flavours of Europeans are available). Solution is RUE (i.e. “regret”) reversed (indicated by “backing”) and followed by OPEN (i.e. sporting “competition”) once wrapped around or “including” A, like so: EUR-OPE(A)N.

across.text: Concerning smell made by trimming elderly plant
across.explanation: OLFACTORY(i.e. “concerning smell”). Solution is OLD (i.e. “elderly”) with its last letter removed (indicated by “trimming”) and the remainder followed by FACTORY (i.e. industrial “plant”), like so: OL-FACTORY.

across.text: Starter taken off mat that’s greasy
across.explanation: OILY(i.e. “greasy”). Solution is DOILY (i.e. “mat”) with the first letter or “starter taken off”.

across.text: A bit of restraint on a test, say, with a singsong?
across.explanation: INTONATE(i.e. to “singsong” – over to Chambers: “to chant, read or utter in musical tones, singsong or monotone”). “A bit of” indicates the solution has been hidden in the clue, like so: RESTRA(INT ON A TE)ST. Took a white to spot.

across.text: Old writer extremely lazy in public
across.explanation: OPENLY(i.e. “in public”). Solution is O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”) followed by PEN (i.e. “writer”) and LY (i.e. “extremely lazy”, i.e. the first and last letters of “lazy”).

across.text: Post-match meal?
across.explanation: WEDDING BREAKFAST(i.e. a “meal”). Clue plays on WEDDINGS often being referred to as “matches” in cryptic clues; the solution being “a meal served after a wedding”(Chambers). You get the idea.

across.text: A referee turns around holding party hat
across.explanation: FEDORA(i.e. “hat”). Solution is A and REF (short for “referee”) all reversed (indicated by “turns around”) and placed around or “holding” DO (i.e. “party”), like so: FE(DO)R-A.

across.text: Cashmere blend? No idea!
across.explanation: SEARCH ME(i.e. “no idea”). “Blend” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of CASHMERE.

across.text: Plant with a name featured in song
across.explanation: DITTANY(i.e. “plant”). Solution is A and N (a recognised abbreviation of “name”) both placed or “featured in” DITTY (i.e. “song”), like so: DITT(A-N)Y. One nailed from the wordplay, if I’m honest.

down.text: Beat up the middleman?
down.explanation: BATTER. Solution satisfies “beat up” and, playfully, “the middleman”, a reference to cricket and how the wicket upon which they bat is situated in the middle of the field.

down.text: Chance to have managed government department being set up
down.explanation: RANDOM(i.e. “chance”). Solution is RAN (i.e. “to have managed”) followed by MOD (i.e. “government department”, specifically the Ministry of Defence) once reversed (indicated by “being set up” – this being a down clue), like so: RAN-DOM.

down.text: Animal I caught at both ends of a cold country
down.explanation: ICELANDIC(i.e. “of a cold country”). Solution is ELAND (i.e. an “animal”) with I and C (a recognised abbreviation of “caught” used in a number of ball games) placed “at both ends”, like so: I-C-(ELAND)-I-C.

down.text: Former African state captures one large creature for wealthy individual
down.explanation: ZILLIONAIRE(i.e. “wealthy individual”). Solution is ZAIRE (i.e. “former African state”, now the Democratic Republic of the Congo) wrapped around or “capturing” I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”), L (a recognised abbreviation of “large”) and LION (i.e. “creature”), like so: Z(I-L-LION)AIRE.

down.text: Charge defensive structure, we gather
down.explanation: LEVY(i.e. “charge”). “We hear” indicates homophone. Solution is a homophone of LEVEE (i.e. “defensive structure”).

down.text: In a legal position inside the box, being attentive
down.explanation: CONSIDERATE(i.e. “attentive”). Solution is ONSIDE (i.e. “in a legal position” on a sports field) placed “inside” CRATE (i.e. “box”), like so: C(ONSIDE)RATE.

down.text: Canoodle endlessly with one wooing a sorcerer
down.explanation: NECROMANCER(i.e. “sorcerer”). Solution is NECK (i.e. to “canoodle”) with its last letter removed (indicated by “endlessly”) and the remainder followed by ROMANCER (i.e. “one wooing”), like so: NEC-ROMANCER.

down.text: Refuse place in cheap spa rebuilt around river
down.explanation: SCRAPHEAP(i.e. “refuse place”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “rebuilt”) of CHEAP SPA wrapped “around” R (a recognised abbreviation of “river”), like so: SC(R)APHEAP.

down.text: Key place for astronauts to hydrate?
down.explanation: SPACE BAR. Solution satisfies “key” and, playfully, “place for astronauts to hydrate”. I’ll admit this did raise a chuckle when I twigged it.

down.text: Dean centralising revolutionary method of education
down.explanation: DISTANCE LEARNING(i.e. “method of education”, e.g. the Open University). “Revolutionary” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of DEAN CENTRALISING.

down.text: Fail to meet comedian
down.explanation: STAND UP(i.e. “fail to meet”). When hyphenated, the solution also satisfies “comedian”.

down.text: Money boxes at centre of big game
down.explanation: PATIENCE(i.e. card “game”). Solution is PENCE (i.e. “money”) wrapped around or “boxing” AT and I (i.e. “centre of big”, i.e. the middle letter of “big”), like so: P(AT-I)ENCE.

down.text: Keep primary vehicle with no resistance
down.explanation: MAINTAIN(i.e. “keep”). Solution is MAIN (i.e. “primary”) followed by TRAIN (i.e. “vehicle”) once the R has been removed (indicated by “with no resistance” – R being a recognised abbreviation of “resistance”), like so: MAIN-TAIN.

down.text: Weak argument for demolishing a scarecrow?
down.explanation: STRAW MAN. Solution satisfies “weak argument for demolishing” – Chambers offers: “a sham opponent or argument set up for the sake of disputation” – and “scarecrow”.

down.text: Singer’s town on TV in need of a clean?
down.explanation: DUSTY SPRINGFIELD(i.e. “singer”). Clue plays on SPRINGFIELD being the setting ofThe Simpsons(i.e. “town on TV”) and DUSTY being “in need of a clean”.

down.text: Fashionable sort of women’s garment – golly!
down.explanation: TEDDY BOY(i.e. “fashionable sort”). Solution is TEDDY (i.e. “women’s garment”) followed by BOY (i.e. “golly”, both exclamations).

down.text: Leader upset religious fellow briefly
down.explanation: TSAR(i.e. “leader”). Solution is RASTA (i.e. “religious fellow”, short for Rastafarian) with the last letter removed (indicated by “briefly”) and the remainder reversed (indicated by “upset” – this being a down clue).

down.text: Sports team’s driver, perhaps
down.explanation: CLUB. Solution satisfies “sports team” and “driver, perhaps” – other species of golf club are available.

down.text: Park attendant with cry of annoyance outside glass house
down.explanation: ORANGERY(i.e. “glass house”). Solution is RANGER (i.e. “park attendant”) placed in or having “outside” OY! (i.e. “cry of annoyance”), like so: O(RANGER)Y.

down.text: Dog, say, to depart – barking
down.explanation: TETRAPOD(i.e. “dog, say” – other four-legged creatures are available). “Barking” indicates anagram, as in being mad. Solution is an anagram of TO DEPART.

down.text: Partner nods when moving communication device
down.explanation: TRANSPONDER(i.e. “communication device”). “When moving” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of PARTNER NODS.

down.text: Pre-prepared meal was bland according to Spooner
down.explanation: PACKED LUNCH(i.e. “pre-prepared meal”). Solution is a “Spoonerism” of LACKED PUNCH (i.e. “was bland”).

down.text: Track feature of hindbrain that’s active with physical education
down.explanation: HAIRPIN BEND(i.e. “track feature”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “that’s active”) of HINDBRAIN and PE (a recognised abbreviation of “physical education”).

down.text: Watery drink picked up in Thames-side location
down.explanation: RUNNYMEDE(i.e. “Thames-side location”). Solution is RUNNY (i.e. “watery”) followed by a homophone (indicated by “picked up”) of MEAD (i.e. “drink”), like so: RUNNY-MEDE.

down.text: Where bulb may go, covering part of corn plant
down.explanation: SEA ROCKET(i.e. “plant”). Solution is SOCKET (i.e. “where bulb may go”) wrapped around or “covering” EAR (i.e. “part of corn”), like so: S(EAR)OCKET. Another solved from the wordplay alone.

down.text: Fussy sort of governess, ultimately with heart to accept learner
down.explanation: STICKLER(i.e. “fussy sort”). Solution is S (i.e. “governess, ultimately”, i.e. the last letter of “governess”) followed by TICKER (slang for one’s “heart”) once wrapped around or “accepting” L (a recognised abbreviation of “learner” used on L-plates), like so: S-TICK(L)ER.

down.text: Captain leaving for culinary competition
down.explanation: COOK-OFF(i.e. “culinary competition”). Solution is “Captain” James COOK followed by OFF (i.e. “leaving”).

down.text: Father to cough up a fruit
down.explanation: PAPAYA(i.e. “fruit”). Solution is PA (i.e. “father”) followed by PAY (i.e. “to cough up”) and A.

down.text: Guard posted on railway
down.explanation: SENTRY(i.e. “guard”). Solution is SENT (i.e. “guard”) followed by RY (a recognised abbreviation of “railway”).

down.text: Oscar regularly broke instrument
down.explanation: OBOE(i.e. musical “instrument”). Solution is O (“Oscar” in the phonetic alphabet) followed by BOE (i.e. “regularly broke”, i.e. every other letter ofBROKE).
